alert.note: Alert for Arkansas; Bradley; Cleveland; Desha; Drew; Faulkner; Grant; Jefferson; Lincoln; Lonoke; Pulaski; Saline (Arkansas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Excessive Heat Warning issued June 28 at 3:43AM CDT until June 28 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Little Rock
info.description: ...EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 1 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 8 PM CDT THIS EVENING... ...EXCESSIVE HEAT WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 8 PM CDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...For the Excessive Heat Warning today, dangerously hot conditions with heat index values over 110 expected. For the Excessive Heat Warning tomorrow, dangerously hot conditions with heat index over 110 expected. * WHERE...Portions of central and southeast Arkansas. * WHEN...For the Excessive Heat Warning today, from 1 PM this afternoon to 8 PM CDT this evening. For the Excessive Heat Warning tomorrow, from noon to 8 PM CDT Thursday. * IMPACTS...Extreme heat and humidity will significantly increase the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those working or participating in outdoor activities. * WHAT: Expect heat index values at or above 105 Wednesday. Heat index values may exceed 110 for Thursday. * WHERE: Portions of central, eastern, north central and southeast Arkansas. * WHEN: For the Heat Advisory, from noon Wednesday to noon CDT Thursday. For the Excessive Heat Warning, from noon to 8 PM CDT Thursday. * IMPACTS: Extreme heat and humidity will significantly increase the potential for heat related illnesses, particularly for those working or participating in outdoor activities.
info.instruction: Drink plenty of fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and check up on relatives and neighbors. Young children and pets should never be left unattended in vehicles under any circumstances. Take extra precautions if you work or spend time outside. When possible reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat stroke. Wear lightweight and loose fitting clothing when possible. To reduce risk during outdoor work, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an emergency! Call 9 1 1.
